questions.question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the clinic presenting with swelling in the upper quadrant of her left breast. She reports changes in the skin and surrounding nipple areola complex as well. All of the following are risk factors for this condition except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D)Multiparity Explanation : Multiparity is not a risk factor for breast carcinoma. The clinical presentation of a 35-year-old female with swelling in the upper quadrant of her breast with skin changes in the skin and the surrounding nipple-areola complex is highly suggestive of carcinoma of the breast. Risk factors for breast carcinoma : Risk factors Relative risk Female gender. Increasing age. (Option C) Germline mutations of high penetrance. Strong family history (>1 first-degree relative, young age, multiple cancers). Personal history of breast cancer. High breast density. >4.0 Germline mutations of moderate penetrance. High-dose radiation to the chest at a young age. Family history (1 first-degree relative). 2.1-4.0 Early menarche (age <12 years). (Option B) Late menopause (age >55 years). Late first pregnancy (age >35 years). Nulliparity. Absence of breastfeeding. Exogenous hormone therapy. Postmenopausal obesity. Physical inactivity. High alcohol consumption. (Option A) 1.1-2.0 Relative risk is the likelihood of developing invasive carcinoma compared to women without any risk factors. Protective factors Early full term pregnancy Multiparity Lactation and breastfeeding Late menarche and early menopause Reference: Robbins and Cotran Textbook of Pathology, 10th Edition, Page 1047

questions.question: Mutations in which of the following genes is not associated with breast cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D) CHEK 1 Explanation : The CHEK1 gene mutation is not linked to breast cancer, whereas the CHEK2 mutation is indeed associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Genetic disorders associated with breast cancer : High penetrance mutations (>4-fold risk, 3-7% of breast cancers) Gene % of single-cell cancers Associated tumors BRCA1 (Option A) 55% Breast, ovarian (~20%–40%), fallopian tube, pancreas, and prostate. BRCA2 35% Breast, ovarian (~10%–20%), pancreas, and prostate. Associated with male breast cancer. TP53 <1% Breast, sarcoma, leukemia, and brain tumors. PTEN Breast, thyroid, and endometrium. STK11 (Option B) Breast, ovarian, colon, and pancreas. CDH1 (Option C) Breast, gastric signet ring cell carcinoma, and colon. PALPB2 Breast, pancreas, and prostate. Moderate penetrance germline mutations (2- to 4-fold increased risk; 5-10% of breast cancers) ATM 5% CHEK2 Prostate, thyroid, colon, and kidney. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Textbook of Pathology, 10th Edition, Page 1049

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman presents for her routine mammogram, which reveals microcalcifications in the right breast. She has no significant family history of breast cancer and is asymptomatic. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on histopathology, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ductal Carcinoma in Situ Explanation : The histopathological image shows features consistent with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), including malignant cells confined within the ductal system without invasion into surrounding tissue. This correlates with the clinical scenario of microcalcifications detected on mammography, a common presentation of DCIS. Types of DCIS : Comedo It may occasionally produce a vague nodularity but is often detected as clustered or linear and branching areas of calcification. Two features define it: Tumor cells with pleomorphic, high-grade nuclei. Areas of central necrosis. Cribriform It has rounded (cookie cutter–like) spaces, often filled with calcified secretory material. Micropapillary It produces complex bulbous protrusions without fibrovascular cores. Papillary It produces true papillae with fibrovascular cores that lack a myoepithelial cell layer. Solid The duct is full of cells and becomes solid. Histological images of

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presented with a palpable breast lump detected during a routine self-examination. A biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma (IDC). Which of the following is not a subtype of IDC? 1. Tubular carcinoma 2. Medullary carcinoma 3. Colloid carcinoma 4. Lobular carcinoma 5. Papillary carcinoma 6. Apocrine carcinoma 7. Secretory carcinoma 8. Myofibroblastoma 9. Angiosarcoma
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D) 4, 8, 9 Explanation : Lobular carcinoma, myofibroblastoma, and angiosarcoma are types of lobular and stromal breast tumors, while all others are subtypes of infiltrating ductal carcinoma (IDC). Infiltrating ductal carcinoma: Special Types of IDC: Tubular carcinoma: Good prognosis. Mucinous or Colloid Carcinoma- Signet ring cells on biopsy and FNAC: Chicken wire blood vessels. Medullary carcinoma- Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate. Apocrine carcinoma. Metaplastic carcinoma. Papillary carcinoma Secretary carcinoma: Occurs in younger females. Inflammatory carcinoma- Peau d'orange appearance with Poor prognosis Reference: Robbins and Cotran Textbook of Pathology, 10th Edition, Page 1055-58

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents with discomfort in her left breast. Mammography reveals a suspicious mass. Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is performed. Based on the histopathological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is associated with the worst prognosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D)Inflammatory carcinoma Explanation : Inflammatory breast carcinoma has a poor prognosis, with extensive invasion of subdermal lymphovascular channels and a 3-year survival rate of less than 10%. Poor prognostic factors for invasive breast carcinoma: Axillary lymph node status and metastases (via internal mammary lymph nodes). Distant metastases. Tumor size greater than 2 cm. Locally advanced disease with skin or lymphovascular invasion within lymphatics or small capillaries. Inflammatory carcinoma. Absence of ER , PR , and HER2 expression. Inflammatory Breast Carcinoma: It presents as breast erythema, swelling, and skin thickening. TNM staging - T4D Edematous skin is tethered to the breast by Cooper ligaments and mimics orange peel or peau d’orange . Microscopy: No inflammation is present. Diffuse lymphovascular space plugging with carcinoma cells in dermal lymphatics. The presentation can be confused with a breast infection, leading to delayed diagnosis. Usually high grade with very poor prognosis. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 1058

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman presents with a newly diagnosed left-sided breast mass on routine mammography. Core needle biopsy shows the following findings. Further molecular study revealed the involvement of the CDH1 gene. Which of the following statements are incorrect concerning this type of breast cancer? 1) Increased E-cadherin expression is observed in tumor cells. 2) Minimal desmoplasia and fibrosis were observed on microscopy. 3) A contralateral breast examination is usually required due to bilateral involvement. 4) It is associated with a poor prognosis compared to other types of breast cancer. 5) Metastatic spread affects leptomeninges and retroperitoneum.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) 1,4 Explanation : Invasive lobular breast carcinoma: CDH1 gene mutation : Decreased E-cadherin levels (also seen in signet ring gastric adenocarcinoma). (Statement 1) Clinically: Bilateral and multicentric lesions; if one breast has ILC, both breasts should be examined. (Statement 3) Microscopy Features: The tumor cells are dyscohesive, present back to back, and are called Indian file pattern. Shows minimal desmoplasia and fibrosis. (Statement 2) Unaffected ducts surrounded by tumor cells called the targetoid spread. Tumor cells trying to enter unaffected ducts are called pagetoid spread. It can contain signet ring cells , with little mucin in some places. Metastatic spread to the peritoneum and leptomeninges is called carcinomatous meningitis.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about Paget's disease of the breast? 1. It is an in-situ cancer. 2. Presence of Paget cells is needed for diagnosis. 3. Underlying carcinoma is usually LCIS. 4. Immunostaining is positive for carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). Which of the above are true statements?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B)1,2, and 4 Explanation : Paget’s disease Is an in-situ cancer.(Statement 1) The presence of Paget cells is needed for diagnosis. These cells are large atypical cells seen infiltrating and disrupting the epidermis of nipple and areola.(Statement 2) Gross features Eczematous Changes causes redness, scaling, and crusting and may involve ulceration in advanced cases. Flattening or inversion of the nipple is common. Lesions may appear well-demarcated or diffuse, spreading to the surrounding skin of the breast. May produce serous or bloody discharge The underlying carcinoma is usually ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).(Statement 3) Immunostaining is positive for CEA.(Statement 4) Histopathology: Presence of Paget cells (Paget cells are pathognomonic): Large, atypical cells found within the nipple and areola epidermis. Epidermal invasion: Paget cells infiltrate and disrupt the normal epidermal architecture. Underlying breast carcinoma: Histological examination may reveal associated breast carcinoma, guiding treatment decisions. Paget’s Disease of Bone (Osteitis Deformans) is a chronic disorder of bone remodeling characterized by excessive bone resorption followed by disorganized bone formation. Presents with Bone pain, deformities (e.g., bowed legs, enlarged skull), pathological fractures and hearing loss (if skull is affected- cranial nerve compression) X-ray - Mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions "Cotton wool" appearance in skull and thickened cortical bone Complications: Osteoarthritis Fractures Sarcomatous transformation (osteosarcoma) Treatment: Bisphosphonates and Calcitonin for pain relief Paget’s Disease of the Vulva is a rare intraepithelial adenocarcinoma of the vulva, often associated with underlying malignancy. Presents with pruritus (persistent itching), erythematous , scaly , or velvety lesions on the vulva, burning sensation or discomfort Histopathology: Large cells with abundant pale cytoplasm ( Paget cells ) within the epidermis Diagnosis: Biopsy + Immunohistochemistry: Positive for CK7 and CEA

questions.question: You are provided with results of receptor status from the biopsy obtained from a patient’s breast lump. You realize that her molecular subtype carries a low proliferative rate and a better prognosis. Which of the following will not be the likely histological subtype in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : B) Medullary carcinoma Explanation : The biopsy results obtained from a patient’s breast lump carrying a low proliferative rate (better prognosis) is indicative of a luminal type A malignancy. Among the given options, medullary carcinoma of the breast does not belong to luminal type A; rather it is a luminal type B malignancy. Molecular classification of breast cancer is based on the results of receptor status such as ER, PR and HER2. Molecular classification of breast cancer : Classification Hormone receptor HER2/Neu Others Luminal A Positive (either or both ER/PR) Negative Ki-67 low Luminal B Positive (either or both ER/PR) Negative / Positive Ki-67 high Basal type (triple -ve) Negative Negative Ki-67 usually high HER2/neu enriched Negative Positive Ki-67 high Claudin low Negative Negative Claudin low Luminal A (Low proliferation rate) Tubular carcinoma (Option A ruled out). Papillary carcinoma ( Option C ruled out). Mucinous carcinoma (Option D ruled out). Low-grade ILC. Luminal B (High proliferation rate) High-grade ILC. HER2/Neu rich Apocrine carcinoma. Micropapillary carcinoma. Triple-negative Medullary carcinoma. (Option B) Metaplastic carcinoma. Secretory carcinoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma. Breast cancers with ER/PR+ receptor status usually have a low rate of proliferation and a better prognosis, unlike those with ER/PR-, as is the case with medullary carcinoma. Hence, it is less likely to be the histological subtype in this patient. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of Disease, 10th edition. Page 1049, 1056-1058) Bailey and Love, Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 931

questions.question: A patient with a lump in her left breast is subjected to a biopsy. Subsequent immunohistochemistry was done and the image is given below. After an MDT discussion, a decision was made to prescribe Trastuzumab as the appropriate management for this patient. What would have been the diagnosis based on the above clinical scenario?
questions.explanation: membranes rather than the nucleus suggest the diagnosis of a HER2 receptor rich breast carcinoma. Apocrine carcinoma is one of the two most common HER2 receptor-rich subtypes of invasive breast carcinoma, the other one being micropapillary carcinoma. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that acts by inhibiting the HER2 receptors and prevents further growth of the tumor, since HER2 receptor rich tumors respond well to HER2 inhibitor therapy. Medullary carcinoma (Option B) is a triple negative subtype. Tubular and papillary carcinomas (Option C and D) are ER/PR positive subtypes hence considered Luminal A.

questions.question: A biopsy taken from a patient's breast lump is subjected to histopathological examination. Upon staining, it is found to be a luminal breast carcinoma with a high proliferative rate. Overexpression of which of the following cellular proteins has led to this interpretation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ki-67 Explanation : Ki-67 is a nuclear protein associated with cellular proliferation . It is <14% in Luminal A and >14% in Luminal B. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 1048, Fig 23.13.

questions.question: Which of the following parameters is not assessed in the Bloom-Richardson scoring system?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Size of the tumor Explanation: The size of the tumor is a part of the Van Nuys Prognostic Index and it is not assessed in the BLoom-Richardson scoring ssystem Bloom-Richardson scoring system (Also known as Nottingham grading system) The parameters include: Nuclear pleomorphism (Option A) refers to variations in the size and shape of cell nuclei. Tubule formation (Option B) , which assesses the degree of glandular formation in tumor tissue. Mitotic count (Option D) indicates the number of actively dividing cells per high-power field. Each parameter is assigned from 1 to 3 points according to the degree of deviation from normal breast epithelium. Score Grade 3-5 I 6 or 7 II 8 or 9 III Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 872. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5161065/
